In

beskuldigde ingevolge art 78(2) vir observasie

9(a)

(b) nie. Bowendien kon die inhoud van die verslag

Aangesien dit vir die verhoorhof geblyk het

bring nie of om 'n gevolglike bevel.te maak nie.

word
uitgereik: (1) Die bevinding dat die
beskuldigde
ontoerekeningsvatbaar was ten tyde van die handeling

sections.facts: The respondent, MPHUMELELO MAGONGO, was tried in the Nelspruit Regional Court for the murder of a two‑year‑old child. Two eyewitnesses, Kesiah Mashele and Jobe Myburgh, described how Magongo seized the child, swung him and struck him against a low wall. Magongo pleaded not guilty, claimed partial memory loss, alleged he had taken traditional medicine ("muti") and was suffering from a sudden illness. The trial court observed an extremely abnormal pattern of conduct – entering his family home, locking the door, lighting matches, throwing sleeping children out of a window, beating a family member with a church stick and ultimately killing the small child – and concluded that such conduct could only be explained by a mental disorder, finding him not criminally responsible at the time of the act.
sections.issues: 1. Whether Magongo was criminally accountable (toerekeningsvatbaar) for the murder at the time it was committed. 2. Whether the trial court complied with the procedural requirements of sections 78(2) and 79 of the Criminal Procedure Act 1977 in determining his mental capacity. 3. Whether the finding of unsound mind under section 78(6) is valid in the absence of the required psychiatric reports.
sections.principles: Section 78(1) of the Criminal Procedure Act allows a finding of unsound mind if the accused was suffering from a mental disorder at the time of the offence. Section 78(2) mandates that such issues be investigated in accordance with section 79, which requires at least two independent psychiatric assessments and written reports. The court must not render a section 78(6) finding unless the procedural safeguards of sections 78(2) and 79 are satisfied. Precedent cases such as S v Chretien, S v Bailey, S v Campher, S v Arnold and S v Mogorosi reinforce these procedural requirements.
sections.application: The appellate court noted that only a single psychiatrist’s report had been produced and that it expressly stated an inability to give an opinion due to insufficient information. This report failed to meet the statutory requirement of at least two expert opinions under section 79(1)(b). Consequently, the trial court’s finding that Magogo was not accountable under section 78(6) was made without the requisite procedural foundation and therefore could not stand.
sections.conclusion: The appeal was allowed. The finding of unsound mind was set aside and the matter was remitted to the trial court for a fresh hearing in accordance with sections 78(2) and 79 of the Criminal Procedure Act. The accused is to be detained at Weskoppies Hospital for the mentally ill pending the decision of the State President.
